description: From Middle English thrugh, thruch, thruh, metathetic variants of thurgh, thurh, from Old English √æurh, from Proto-Germanic *√æurhw (‚Äúthrough‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *trÃ•h‚ÇÇk ∑e, suffixed zero-grade  from *terh‚ÇÇ- (‚Äúto pass through‚Äù) + *-k ∑e (‚Äúand‚Äù). Cognate with Scots throch (‚Äúthrough‚Äù), West Frisian troch (‚Äúthrough‚Äù), Dutch door (‚Äúthrough‚Äù), German durch (‚Äúthrough‚Äù), Gothic êå∏êå∞êåπêçÇêå∑ (√æairh, ‚Äúthrough‚Äù), Latin trans (‚Äúacross, over, through‚Äù), Albanian t√´rthor (‚Äúthrough, around‚Äù), Welsh tra (‚Äúthrough‚Äù). See also thorough.

entries.meaning: Passing from one side of something to the other.
examples: Interstate highways form a nationwide system of through roads.

entries.meaning: Finished; complete.
examples: They were through with laying the subroof by noon.

entries.meaning: Without a future; done for.
examples: After being implicated in the scandal, he was through as an executive in financial services.

entries.meaning: No longer interested; wearied or turned off by experience.
Proceeding from origin to destination without delay due to change of equipment.
examples: The through flight through Memphis was the fastest.

entries.meaning: (soccer) In possession of the ball beyond the last line of defence but not necessarily the goalkeeper; through on goal.
examples: With the Swifts calling for offside the striker was through and only a great save from McIlravey prevented the opener.

entries.meaning: From one side to the other by way of the interior.
From one end to the other.
examples: Others slept; he worked straight through.

entries.meaning: During a period of time; throughout
To the end.
examples: He said he would see it through.

entries.meaning: Completely.
examples: Leave the yarn in the dye overnight so the color soaks through.

entries.meaning: Out into the open.
examples: The American army broke through at Saint-L√¥.

entries.meaning: A large slab of stone laid in a dry-stone wall from one side to the other; a perpend.
From one side of an opening to the other.
Entering, then later leaving.
examples: I drove through the town at top speed without looking left or right.

entries.meaning: Surrounded by (while moving).
examples: We slogged through the mud for hours before turning back and giving up.

entries.meaning: By means of.
examples: This team believes in winning through intimidation.

entries.meaning: In consequence of; as a result of.
examples: Our minds and hearts are corrupted with the Adamic virus at birth, and through a lifetime of sin and tragedy, our hearts and thoughts get more evil and more corrupted as we experience life's tragedies.

entries.meaning: (Canada, US) To (or up to) and including, with all intermediate values.
examples: from 1945 through 1991;‚ÄÉ the numbers 1 through 9;‚ÄÉ your membership is active through March 15, 2013

description: From Middle English thrugh, √ærou»ù, throgh, from Old English √ær≈´h (‚Äútrough, conduit, pipe; box, chest; coffin, tomb‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *√ær≈´hs (‚Äúexcavated trunk, trough‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *terh‚ÇÉu- (‚Äúto rub, turn, drill, bore‚Äù).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A coffin, sarcophagus or tomb of stone; a large slab of stone laid on a tomb.
